row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: NEW JUDICIAL REFORMS.
div.p: The vernacular Press appears to be greatly disturbed at the new judicial reforms. Our Arabic contemporaries have expressed themselves as strongly opposed to the new scheme of holding Assize Courts whereby they allege that, both as regards the constitution of the Court and the procedural justice is not likely to be impartially administered. It is assumed that the Courts are to be everally constituted of three Counsellors of the Court of Appeal, but with power to the Ministry of Justice to replace one of them by Judge of First Instance. But, of course, ring to the absurd and ostrich-like policy of never taking the publicinto confidence until the Ro icon has been crossed, it is impossible to say whether this surmise is correct. However, assuming that the vox populi is on this occasion accurate, the native | Press appears to have ome reason on its side. The main ground of complaint is that the Judges of First Instance are removable at the will and pleasure of the Ministry of Justice, and that they will therefore think of the permanency of their posts, rather than of the rights of the accused persons who are brought before them. Such con iderations might possibly operate on the minds Of the Judges of First Instance, having regard to the unceremonious way in which their tenure of office has sometimes been treated, and also to the criticisms to which their judgments are abjected by the Judicial Adviser in his Rep its as well as by the "Comité de Surveillance." The other matter which is exercising na ve opinion, as expressed by their newspapers, the revocation of the power of appeal, which abrogates the rights and privileges hitherto enjoyed by persons accused of crime in this country. Upon this point we must admit that a reactionary tendency is observable, seeing that in all other countries the power of appeal is being considerably widened. We cannot of course foreshadow with any degree of certainty what will be the exact methods of procedure, but one thing we most earnestly hope, and that is that no discretionary powers, as regards appeal, will be conferred on the judges, for, one of the wisést who er graced the English Bench in the last century held it as his opinion that the co ferment of such a power placed the judge in most invidious position, for no judge would ser. be likely to grant an appeal when he think that he is right, and he is generally wrong when he thinks himself most right. The native Press asserts that the Legislative Council as a body is dead against the new proposals, but we are afraid that if such be the case, that consideration is hardly likely to carry very great' weight.

div.head:
RUSSIAN REFORMS.
RESCRIPT BY TSAR.
LEGISLATIVE CHANGES.

div.p: The Tsar has issued a decree declaring that, in conjunction with the undeviating maintenance and immutability of the fundamental laws of the Empire, it is the duty of the Government to meet any change in the needs of the 1 people when the time is ripe for the same, even though it involves essential innovations in 1 legislation.

His Majesty directs his Ministers to consider the possibility of introducing various administrative reforms and to report to him as early as possible. The reforms are not to involve any practical change in the system of government.

The proposals include the bringing of the peasant laws into conformity with general legislation, measures for ensuring the application of the law for all alike, the establishing of legal responsibility for arbitrary acts, ensuring independence of the Courts, extension of the powers held by local institutions and measures to make them more representative, the revisiga of exceptional laws against enemies of public order, the introduction of which involved a grave extension of the powers held by the administrative authorities, the revision of religious restrictions, the revision of the disabilities attaching to watives in certain territories, and the revision of the Press laws in order to enable the Press to wortbily fulfil its mission of interpreting reasonable strivings for Russia's advantage.
(Reuter.)

A rescript of the Tsar announces that he is having reforms studied with a view to giving the peasantry the position of truly free men. Other reforms include the participation of elected bodies in the administration of public affairs, the bettering of the condition of the working classes, the abrogation of the restrictive Press regime, and religious toleration.
(Havus.)
The newspapers protess an almost unqualified satisfaction with the decree, which the Noroya Vremya describes as the second enfranchisement for the pelaut.
(Reuter.)

A Government communiqué declares that the reform movement initiated by the Zemstvos is alien to the Russian people, who remain true to the old State organisation hallowed by centuries. The Government must oppose any anti Government meeting, State servants being specially held responsible for any contraventions of the law in this respect. The communiqué also calls upon the Press to assist in calming society.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
A SUPERHUMAN TASK
VESSELS DANGEROUSLY
DEFECTIVE.
div.p: The Rus, in an outspoken article, say, that the time has passed for silence. The state of the Navy renders the task imposed on Admiral Rodjestvensky a superhuman one. The vessels destined for his reinforcement, now at Cron stadt and Libau, are dangerously defective.
(Reuter.)
The rumours that Holland would place Sabang Bay at the disposal of the Baltic Fleet are devoid of foundation.
(Reuter.
Russia has demanded the restitution of the ammunition, mentioned on the 24th inst., on the ground that it was intended for the Legation guard.
(Reuter.)

es New DOCTORS, ETC.- The Director-General id of the Sanitary Service has authorised Dr. le Selim Nammour to practise as a physician in of Egypt, Messrs. Kevork Tchavonchyan, Emile

div.head: CAMPING OUT AT CAIRO.--
div.p: An English lady, who is coming out to Cairo, has made arrangements with one or two friends to live in tents outside the city. The necessary permission has been granted to the camping party, who expect to have a very enjoyable time in this improvisuu hotel.

div.head: MAN HACKED TO PIECES. -
div.p: From Kotour, near Tantah, comes a most unpleasant story of an Arab who, finding a husband to stand in the way of a intrigue, tells upon him in his sleep and hacked him to pieces with an axe. The woman who prompted the crime at once denounced the murderer, who has confessed his guilt.

div.head: R. BERKS.-
div.p: The quadrille party given by the warrant officers, staff sergeants, and sergeants of the 2nd Battalion R. Berks Regiment out Boxing Night was a great success. A large number of friends of the Berks were present and a very enjoyable evening was spent, daucmug being engaged in with the greatest animation ap tu a late hour..

div.head: ENTERTAINMENT.-
div.p: Mr. Scott-Leslie, the well known runciter, gave a most amusing entertainment with Mr. D. Norton at the Hotel du N11, Cairo, last night. His stories were as well told as uver, while the 'Lesson from the Water Mill' and Albert Chevalier's two sketches made a great uit. Mr. Norton's playing was very much appreciated, especially West's Tarantella.'

div.head: "EviL COMMUNICATIONS” Ero.-
div.p: The depraying example of the Alexandria municipal scandals of a short time ago, whereby it was made evident huw easy municipal officials can make money by illicit means, has evidently

influenced the most adjacent Municipality at round the coast. We regret to learn that numerous irregularities have been brought to ral light in the operations of the Municipality at els Beirut. A commission appointed to investigate in the matter will also examine the accounts of
all the commercial and industrial societies who have engaged to pay a fraction of their profits to the Municipality of the town.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA FIRE.
div.p: At the meeting of the assurance agents yesterday afternoon, Mr. Meclavitch was appointed as expert to examine the building on behalf of the companies interested. Mr. Mareschal was appointed by the owner of the Old Bourse Building to act with Mr. Meclavitch as assessor.

The assessors for the stock of cigarettes, tobacco, material, etc., in the cigarette manufactory are Mr. Protopapas, for Mr. Laureng, the manager, and Mr. Agopian, for the insurance companies interested.
The committee of inspection will consist of Messrs. Barker, Behrend, Hewat and Manley. Several millions of cigarettes have been destroyed
Mr. Allen Borman, of Messrs. Borman & Co., Alexandria, has been appointed assessor of the damages, so far as concerns the bar and stores of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi.
The Journal du Caire published the following telephonic message yesterday :
"C'est là que le feu s'est déclaré, causé, assure-t-on, par un court-circuit électrique.

"Es quelques instants tout n'a été qu'un brasier et le sinistre n'a pas tardé à se propager à tout l'édifice et successivement aux bureaux de l'Egyptian Gazette, puis aux magasins Walker et Meimarachi.
"Tous les efforts des pompiers ont été impuissants et on a pu sauver fort peu de chose."

The statement as regards the offices of the Egyptian Gazette is erroneous. The conflagration, thanks to the efforts of the Alexandria Fire Brigade, was brought to a standstill at the partition wall between our printing works and' Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi's stores. But the flames came so near that at one time they managed to creep through an opening at the top of the wall. They were, however, at once extinguished. The only damage done in our premises was by the water, which did some harm to our bales of printing paper,

We are requested to state that Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's branch at Alexandria can execute any orders as in the past. The temporary entrance is at the back of the premises. The greatest expedition will be used in order to re-establish the bar and the stores in their original state.
All the perishable goods at the stores will be sold by public auction to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock in the okella behind the stores.

div.head: KAFR AMMAR COLLISION.
div.p: We hear that the inquiry held by the Railway Administration into the recent railway accident at Kafr Ammar has not yet established who was responsible for the collision. The driver appears to have run past all the signals, which were against him, but happily put on the brake as soon as he saw the train in front of him. He was slightly injured in the collision. Besides the brake and luggage van, dining-car, and kitchen-car of the "train de luxe," four goods carriages, including a cattle truck belonging to the slow train, were badly damaged.

Six persons, as well as MM. Bassiglia and Disertis, were injured, though much less severely. M. Bassiglia, whose condition was reported to be very serious, is progressing as favorably as can be expected.
A new dining-car has arrived just in time to replace that destroyed in the accident.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin records two cases (one fatal) and a death at Suez, one case at Port Said, and one recovery at Toukh.

div.head: SUICIDES.
div.p: Mr. Bensilum, & British subject lately attached to the Wakfs Administration as engineer, has disappeared after leaving a few lines scrawled in pencil addressed to his mother, whose pardon he implored for the suicide he meditated. No trace of the unfortunate young man has been discovered.
One Tadrôs Ibrahim as shot himself in a native hotel at Assiout. The reasons for the act are unknown.

div.head: ENGLISH FURNITURE IN EGYPT.
div.p: The fame of Maple & Co., the largest furnishing establishment in the world, is firmly established here. Our local furniture manufacturers can of course turn out some fair samples of furniture, but they all lack that taste and distinction which are the essential cachet of the workmanship of the great Tottenham Court-road firm. Moreover, Maple's prices compare most favorably with those of local furniture manufacturers, and when the superiority of the workmanship is taken into consideration the real economy of buying furniture direct trom England is apparent. With the facilities for river transport to Cairo and the South. there is very little trouble attached. Messrs. Maple and Co. have arranged for Mr. Oliver, one of their leading representatives, who visited Egypt last year, to be in this country again from the first week in January (the exact date will be duly announced by us). His address will be "Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo," where all letters making appointments should be directed. He will have with him photographs and sketches of all the latest productions in English-made furniture of the best class, together with a good selection of patterns of English-made carpets, brocades,and furniture coverings, and will be happy to give expert advice on all matters in connection with modern furnishing and decoration.

div.head: A KURSAAL FOR CAIRO.
div.p: Although the Cairó hotels do their utmost to cater for the amusement of their visitors and organise innumerable "small dances" and fêtes for their clients, yet the want of a Kursaal for the Capital during the season is becoming more and more felt. It is not improbable that a local syndicate may be formed to take up this scheme, but as yet negotiations are still in a very nebulous state. A Kursaal run on the lines of those establishments to be found at the principal fashionable resorts on the Continent would, if properly managed, be sure to pay.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S.
div.p: The small dance given on Monday last at Shepheard's was attended with the usual success. Dancing was kept up till about 1.80 a.m., when several supper parties were given in the grill-room. Among others there we noticed Baron Alb. Alliotti, Mr. and Mrs. MacDonald, M. de la Courwanegz, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert, Mr. Robinson, Sir William and Lady Russell, Capt. Healey, Col. Sir H. H. Oldham, Mr. and Mrs. McLellan, Mr. de Smith, etc.

div.p: The Savoy is filling very rapidly, many of the old habitués having arrived this week. Among the latest arrivals are Col. and Mrs. Charles Bell, Miss Bell and Miss Stevenson, Col. and Mrs. Jago, Mme. Kate Simon and the Mlles. Simon, Paris, Baron Thomas de Maas and the Misses de Maas, Odessa, Dr. Fricher, Odessa, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. D. London, Mr. Nicolas de Tchitchatchoff, St. Petersburg, Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds, New York, Dr. and Mme. Aufschläger, Hamburg, Mr. C. Turner, Mr. W. H. Pathe, Mr. R. G. Colebrooke and Miss Colebrooke, Mr. V. de Costa Audrade, etc.
The restaurant is full every evening, the Bracale orchestra being one of the great draws. This evening the ladies' orchestra will play at the Savoy.
Next Saturday's dance promises to be very well attended and many dinner parties are already arranged for the evening.
Mr. D. P. MacGillivray entertained a large party of guests on Monday evening at the Savoy Restaurant.
The annual installation banquet of the Grecia Lodge will take place at the Savoy on Tuesday next.
Lady Clarke and a large party are expected at the Savoy among the arrivals by the "Orontes."
Mr. and Mrs. Ellerman, of Ellerman's Line, will be again at the Savoy this year, and are expected shortly.

div.head: THE GARRISON DIRECTORY.
div.p: There are some rather unaccountable mistakes in the recently published Garrison Directory which seem to show rather careless proofreading. In the list of Under Secretaries of State the names of Messrs. Webb and Perry are omitted, and, stranger still, we learn that the post of Adviser to the Ministry of Finance is filled by Sir William Garstin and Mr. Vincent Corbett. To use a stereotyped phrase, "we have received no official intimation of this important change." It is, of course, a mistake, but the world in general, while indulgent to those who misspell addresses, and capable even of pardoning those who deprive Browne of its "e" and commit equally grave offences against the integrity of surnames, is disposed to be exacting when the posts and titles of some of the most important officials in the country are in question.

div.head: RE-ORGANISATION OF GHAFFARIAN
div.p: Keneh, December The new system of ghaffar organise on which is being instituted by the Interior will, it is hoped, be successful in lessening the number of crimes and securing greater safety to the residents. Mr. A. W. Hazel, Interior Inspector, and Mohamed Ali Bey, the Keneb Sub-Mudir, are arranging for carrying out his work in the markaz of Keneh. Ghaffars are being chosen who can be depended on in time of need. The old ghafars have been mostly dismissed. There are two relays of watchmen, one for day work and the other for night. A day ghaffar is to be paid P.T. 60 in the villages and P.T. 75 in the towns. The night ghaffar is to have P.T. 90 in the villages and P.T. 100 in the bandars. The "Sheikh El-Gafar" in the villages will have from P.T. 150 up to P.T. 200, while that of the bandar will have P.T. 300,

There is also an employé called mulab of ghaffirs who is to be appointed from the pensioned employés. His principal duty is to make a night patrol with the ghaffirsthin a radius of 5,000 feddans. This man is not under the orders of the Omdeh, but reports to the Markaz directly. His pay is to be P.1500 & month.

A meeting was held in the Keneh Markaz this morning for the distribution of grants-in-aid to the fikis of kuttabs. The Mudir, the Inspector, the headmaster of the Government school, and many of the notables of the town were prosent. Before the grants were distributed, a chapter from the Koran was recited. The Inspektor of Kuttabs, Sheikh Abd-ul-ate Hallal, made a long! speech to the fikis, exhorting them to maintain order, organisation, and activity in their work, and comparing the great success of the kuttabs this year with that of last year, and explaining the cause of the happy results. The Mudir, Gamal Eddin Bey, also spoke.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but who wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain nombre limits-free discussion.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN. GAZETTE.

Sir, I was disagreeably surprised to read in the Gazette this afternoon & scarcely disguised reflection on the better classes of the Hellenic community of Alexandria, contained in the extracts you published from the Note of the Financial Adviser on the Budget for 1905. That high official states that hashish smuggling reflects unfairly, "especially on the numerous and respected Hellenic community of Alexandria.". In view of the very cordial relations, which have always existed between the Hellenic colony and the English, espeo y at Alexandria, I must stigmatise this reflection as unjustifiable and unwarranted Your newspaper is read by a great many Breeks throughout Egypt and has been characterised by its sympathetic attitude toward the community, 80 the publicity which the Judicial Adviser's strictures will obtain must be a cause of deep annoyance to many ireeks throughout this country. The insinuations are unfair and misleading in the extreme. For example, can Mr. Benachi or Mr. Sinadino be considered in any way responsible for hashish smuggling any more than can any of the respectable members of the British colony be held liable for drunkenness among British sailors or soldiers at Alexandria 1 The Financial Adviser states that the leaders of the Hellenic community at Alexandria "åre no less interested than the Egyptian authorities in pung an end to the present state of things." 1 is an incontestable assertion, but it would have been far better unsaid. The paragraph is he led "A Plain Hint," and you have justly conveyed the general impression which it must reste in every reader's mind by this title. I fail to see why the respectable members of the Hellenic community should be saddled with this disgraceful imputation by the Financial Adviser, any more than the respectable members of the French colonies here should be held responsible for the presence of Parisian demi-mondaines in Egypt. If Alexandria was as near to an English port as it is to the Piræus. I am gure that the British colony in Egypt would have as many "mauvais sujets' ' as we have, and it is only owing to the contiguity of Egypt to Greece and Southern Italy, that the Greek and Italian communities here have so many undesirable members among them. To hold an entire community responsible for the misdeeds of a few of its members is utterly unfair and it is most regrettable that the first Note, which the newly-appointed Financial Adviser has issued, should be characterised by suoh & sad error of judgment.
I am, etc.,

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Princess Henry of Battenberg will probably stay at Assouan for a couple of months this winter, staying till late in March.

Among the visitors staying as the Luxor Hotel we notice the names of Cod It Stidnfek, the Viscount and Viscountess de Courey, Baron and Baroness Profumo, the Bishop of Lucknow and Mrs. Clifford, Vicente de Porttaree, and Professor Sethe.
The Financial Adviser and Mr! - H.' N. Bowden-Smith left for Khartoum yesterday evening.
Dr. - Rücker-Jeniseh, German Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Caire is leaving for Berlin on Saturday next by to Austria Lloyd steamer for Alexandria

Sir William Whittall, President of the British Chamber of Commerce of Constantinople, is coming to Egypt next month. Bir William intends to spend some time at Helouan As he has been suffering from rheumatism lately,
The rank of Moutemaiz has been graciously conferred by H.H. the Khedive on Herz Bey, chief architect of the Wakfs Administration.
Mt. Wakeman Long, the well-known solicitor and advocate in the Court of Appeal of the Mixed Tribunals of Alexandria has been appointed a judge of the Native Court of 1st Instance at Tantah.
Mr. and Mrs. Hogg are leaving Cairo for a trip to Khartoum this evening. 1
Mr. and Mrs. Lang Anderson Jaft Alexandria yesterday morning by the 9 a.m. express for Cairo to pass Christmas week at Ghezireh Palace Hotel
Mr. D. G. - Longworth, former editor-proprietor of the Sphinx, has arrived in Cairo from the Continent.
Mr. H. C. Simpsón, late of the National Bank of Egypt at Alexandria, has entered upon his new and important duties as director of the branch of the National Baat Medinet el-Fayoum.
Mr. Arthur Fraser, late of the Egyptian Markets, Ltd., has entered the University of Aberdeen in order to prepare himself for the ministry

The latest arrivals at the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Hélouan, include the Earl of Crawford, Comte de Galarza, Dr. Crawford Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Hoffmann, Mrs. Siewright, Mr. and Mrs. Erskin, Mr. A. H. Lory, Captain and Mrs. Sieb, Major and Mi Adoopk, Mr. and Mrs. Sternberg.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: La hausse d'hier matin a continué hier aprèsmidi ; tous les cours ont clôturé fermes et en excellento tendance ; le mouvement a été surtout remarquable sur la National Bank et sur l'Agricole, qui présentaient une avance, la première de 1£ et la seconde de $£ sur la cote do samedi dernier. De forts ordres d'achats n'ont cessé d'être portés sur le marché.

Ce matin l'ouverture s'est ressentie de la tendance de la veille. Les cours ont débuté fermes et la cote de Londres nous est parvenue à 22 ; la National Bank et à 9 f l’Agricole, soit une hausse de, 15£ pour la première et 4£ pour la seconde. On assure que ce résultat provient d'importants ordres d'achats commandés d'ici pour le compte de l'Egypte. Aussi, malgré la faiblesse des cotons qui a ramoné la mauvaise humeur dans la corbeille des valeurs, la cote y reste-t-elle presque stationnaire et la tendance excellente. L'ensemble du marché présente, en effet, un bon aspect.- Si l'on ajoute à ces considérations que les petits clients ont en grand nombre liquide leurs situations (à des prix dérisoires, il faut bien le reconnaitre maintenant) on conviendra que l'avenir s'annonce sous des couleurs moins sombres. Tout au plus aurons-nous encore une légère socentuation de la baisse si la situation des cotons va en empirant. Mais si cette si.. tuation s'améliore, on peut prévoir une hausse immédiate et escompter dès à présent une liquidation de fin du mois sans nouvelles complications. Dans tous les cas, x gène actuelle prendra certainement fin apas les fêtes et l'on s'attend alors à une reprise sérieuse et générale.

Ainsi que nous venons de le dire, les cours avaient considérablement haussé hier aprèsmidi. Nous allons relater pour les valeurs les plus mouvementées la réaction, d'ailleurs peu 19 importante, qui s'est produite ce matin à la! suite de la baisse des cotons :
De 21 7/8 la National Bank revient à 213/4, 15 l'Agricole de 9 15/16 à 9 3/4, la Delta Light de 14 5/16 à 14 1/4.
La Salt & Soda, après avoir atteint hier soir 38/9, fléchit aujourd'hui à 37/9.
La Daïra tombe également de 21 3/8 à 21 5,16, la Delta Land de 3 7/8 à 3.13/16.
Les Markets restent sans changement à 22 shellings, vendeurs.
La plupart des autres valeurs restent dans l'ombre et la baisse qu'on y remarque est plutôt nominale.
En fait de transactions, elles ont été nom-14 breuses hier après-midi sur la National Bank et sur l'Agricole ; ce matin il se traite moins d'affaires par suite du malaise qui règne sur le mascht.

(à midi et demi) La baisse continue des cotons a entrainé celle des yaleurs. La National Bank fléchit encore À 22.5/8, l'Agricole à 9 11/16, la Delta Land al! 3 3/4, la Crown Brewery, à 222, la Salt and Soda à 37/3, les Ciments d'Egypte à 105, la Banque d'Athènes à 117, la Nungovich à 9 et les Eaux du Caire à 1000.
Devant l'hésitation croissante du marché les acheteurs se tiennent sur la réserve.

div.head: Délégation Municipale
div.p: (Communication officielle) La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 27 Décembre 1904 à 4 h. p.m.

La Délégation s'occupe de la question d'installation d'une conduite devant amener l'eau filtrée à Ramleh. Elle nomme une sous-commission pour examiner le tracé à suivre et lui faire proposition à cet égard.

Elle charge le Comité des expropriations composé de MM. Abani Bey, Stross et Said Bey pour examiner la question de l'élargissement de la route avoisinant le fort Kom-elDick dont l'entrée est sise en face le Tribunal Indigène de la porte Rosette.

Sur la proposition du Président elle charge l'Administrateur d'étudier un projet de véri. fication des poids employés par les marchands tant au moyen de l'installation des peseurs publics dans les marchés qu'au moyen du poinçonnement par la Municipalité des poids utilisés par les marchands et leur vérification par la suite.
Elle approuve une note tendant à l'application du système des quittances nominatives à la taxe sur les bestiaux et véhicules.
Elles décide de soumettre à la Commission, un projet d'arrêté concernant la police intérieure de l'abattoir.
Elle adjuge à Mr. Autophage la fourniture des articles nécessaires aux rouleaux compresseurs.

div.head: XMAS FESTIVITIES.
div.p: The Christmas Tree fête at the Luxor Hotel! yesterday was a great success. An excellent dinner was offered and everybody was enchanted to have the day kept up in the good old Euclish style. Mr. Pagnon was most heartily Congratulated by his guests on his elaborate preparations for the festivities.

div.head: THE TANZIM.
div.p: The excursions in the neighbourhood of Luxor are among the most renowned and interesting in the world. But there are many invalids who come here and whose strength does not permit them to explore the wonders of Thebes and Karnak. These form the moiety of our visitors, and it is on these that the shortcomings of the town press particularly hard. There is nowhere to walk. True there is a promenade extending northward from the Luxor Hotel for 500 or 600 metres, but this is all. Why should not the Government extend this roud as has already been done at Assouan? A walk here 18 is a gruesome experience. At one time one is choked with dust, at another splashed with mud, and mud of a particularly obnoxious character, for the roads are watered at all hours, and so much water is used that the whole place is swamped, and & passing cart or donkey literally bespalters the unfortunate pedestrian from head to foot.

div.head: THE KAFR AMMAR ACCIDENT.
div.p: Owing to the collision yesterday at Kafr Ammar the train irom Cairo arrived nine hours late. No sleeping car left to-night for Cairo as usual, owing to the collision. Only two cars were attached to the express train, which was minus the restaurant car. A special train was made up for travellers proceeding through to Assouan at 7.30 p.m. under the superintendence of Mr. Western, the divisional and district inspector.

div.head: A LUXOR WANT.
div.p: Another Luxor correspondent writes as follows :

The following facts are, I think, of general interest, and as publication of them in the Egyptian Gazette will probably attract the attention of the Higher officials, and lead to some action on their part, you will render & public service by ventilating the matter.

There has been for a long time back a right of way from the Nile bauk opposite Luxor to two points in the Thebes district; the path is single as far as the south-east corner of the large cultivated area on the left bank of the river, and then divides into two, one track leading direct to the Colossi and the other to the neighbourhood of the Temple of Gurneh. A new railway for the transport of sugar cane has been made on the site of the old path to the Colossi, and the owner of the fields lying immediately to the north of the railway attempts to prevent visitors from passing across the land in this direction. By law what right was the railway that made you the old path; and by what route are visitors to reach Thebes? The lindowner has placed guards carrying heavy sticks, to stop people passing over the fields, and there appears to be some danger of an affair resembling the Sleemant case. Many people object to riding on the railway when the trains are moving, and if they attempt to cross the fields they run the risk of a collision with the landowner's guards. Ofe these two alternatives, are we either to submit to abuse and perhaps violence from the guards, or to run the risk of an accident from the trains! | This question was put unofficially to one of the Government officials in Luxor, and he replied that he would 'write to Cairo for 1 instruction !

Meanwhile, before the instructions arrive, what is to be done if the guards bring on a quarrel by offering violence to tourists when they attenípt to follow the path across the fields ? Or if the visitors ride on the railway and meet with some injury from the trains will the owners of the line be willing to pay damages?
Why was the matter not settled when the railway was being planned? And what is the name of the official whose negligence is the cause of the present difficulty ?

Having followed with interest the progress of the Sleeman affair, I see that it may go hard with any European who becomes involved in a quarrel arising from this disputed right-of-way, and that he may be detained in Egypt for a considerable time at the cost of much annoyance, and perhaps considerable loss and expense to himself, while he awaits the circuit of H.B.M.'s Supreme Consular Court.

The presence of a resident Englishman as consul in Upper Egypt would be an improvement on the present arrangements, for as things' are now there is the daily risk of some fracas occurring which might end in bloodshed, while we 'await instructions. In referring to the possibility of bloodshed I do not wish to lay myself open to the charge of being melodramatic, but suppose a lady is interfered with by these guards, and is knocked off her donkey or struck with a stick, is it likely that any European accompanying her will abstain from thrashing the offender? A general fight might ensue, ending in bloodshed.

Every day numerous visitors go to Thebes, and yesterday I myself had a violent dispute with the guards which happily ended peacefully. In the case of a traveller who does not understand or speak Arabic the action of these guards might be misunderstood, and a serious affair be the result.
I hope you will take some notice of this matter.

div.head: VISITORS LISTS.
div.p: Mr. A. S. Wylie, Miss Richardson, Herr

Karl Kirschneck, Herr Joseph Karl KirschDeck, General and Mrs. Fr. Lance, M. and Mme. Stanislas de Kopirnicki, M. Witold de Kopirnicki, M. W. Fayans, Miss Richardson, Mr. and Mrs. George Watson, Miss H. Gordon, Miss 0. Calloghan, Miss G. Smail, Mr. Fanning, Miss L. Billico, Mr. H. Riek, Mr. A. Holtz, Miss R. Holtz, Miss S. Lissner, Col. and Mrs. Selden Alleu-Day, Rev, C. Connell, Surgeon-Major and Mrs. J. Adcock, Comte de Galarza, M. Syel H. Askari, Mr. Dahl, Mr. and Mrs. Sternberg, Miss Holdane, Miss | H. Clark, Mr. le Dr. and Mme H. Demirdjian, Miss Riek, Dr. Nanny Bey, Mr. Chidell, Mr. Georgiades, Mr. and Mrs. Williby, Mr. and Mrs. Cravan, Mr. R. Page, Mr. and Mrs. Morley,
The British steamer "Serbestan" arrived here from England on the 15th inst. with a special consignment of material and locomotives for the Sudan Government Railways.

The Sudan Government Port Tug"Hawk" left for Sheikh Barghout on the morning of the 17th inst. with Miralai Macauley Bey, Director of Sudan Railways, and Kaimakam Drury Bey, Controller of Sudan Ports, for inspection, returning in the evening.
Bimbashi Cox, of the 3rd Battalion, E. A., is a patient in the Government Hospital here, and had a slight operation performed which turned out successful.

A pharmacy has been opened here by Mr. Fotinos, chemist, of Athens College. This is the first one to be opened in Suakin and has been greatly needed, more especially as lately the natives are beginning to learn the value of medicines.

The Khedivial mail steamer "Calioubieh" left here on the 16th inst. for Suez with Bimbashi Lord, R.E., who is going to Alexandria to take over temporarily the duties of Sudan Agent there from Mr. Hickley. Mr. Hickley will arrive here by the next mail boat.
Mr. Kershaw, civil judge of Suakin, also left by the "Calioubieh," having been transferred to the Civil Courts of Tantah.
The Khedivial mail steamer "Missir" leaves to-day for Suez, and H.E. Miralai Howard Bey, both act for him.
The rain again washed away the railway i line yesterday, and two engines with their
wagons almost sank in a hole. Bimbashi Sowerby, R.E., Chief Engineer of Ways and | Works, immediately prepared a breakdown

gang and wagon, and went to the scene of the | accident. He repaired the damage done in one day. These accidents are likely to occur until the bridges are erected, as the rain comes down in torrents from the mountains and works through a passage anywhere.
